<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 727, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the density of sand by two methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 98, 680, 116]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 120, 809, 349]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 352, 443, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[581, 352, 653, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 203, 397]]<|/det|>
<label>Method 1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 146, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 408, 185, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 408, 920, 442]]<|/det|>
Measure the mass \(m_{1}\) of measuring cylinder A using the top-pan balance, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 452, 920, 471]]<|/det|>
<form>\(m_{1} =\) .................................................... $g$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 481, 727, 500]]<|/det|>
Pour approximately \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of sand into **measuring cylinder A**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 496, 885, 514]]<|/det|>
**The sand is to remain in the measuring cylinder for the rest of the experiment.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 510, 660, 528]]<|/det|>
Measure the volume \(V_{1}\) of sand in measuring cylinder A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 540, 920, 559]]<|/det|>
<form>\(V_{1} =\) .................................................... $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 570, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
Measure the mass \(m_{2}\) of measuring cylinder A and the sand using the top-pan balance, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 616, 920, 635]]<|/det|>
<form>\(m_{2} =\) .................................................... $g$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 644, 752, 663]]<|/det|>
Use your values of \(m_{1}\) and \(m_{2}\) to calculate the mass \(m_{3}\) of the sand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 705, 920, 723]]<|/det|>
<form>\(m_{3} =\) .................................................... $g$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 718, 920, 735]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 747, 181, 766]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 747, 920, 797]]<|/det|>
Calculate a value for the density \(\rho_{1}\) of the sand. Use your values from **(a)**(i) and the equation \(\rho_{1} = \frac{m_{3}}{V_{1}}\). Include a unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 815, 920, 833]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho_{1} =\) .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 845, 180, 863]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 844, 920, 892]]<|/det|>
Describe **one** possible source of inaccuracy in the measurements taken in **method 1**. You may assume that all measurements are taken carefully and involve good experimental practice.

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of hot water in surroundings with different temperatures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 680, 138]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1 and Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 144, 907, 336]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 350, 532, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 381, 144, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 381, 180, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 381, 536, 400]]<|/det|>
Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water into beaker B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 396, 490, 415]]<|/det|>
Place the thermometer in the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 427, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in the appropriate column heading of Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta_{1}\) of the water. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 475, 181, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 475, 635, 492]]<|/det|>
Remove the thermometer from the water in beaker B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 490, 448, 508]]<|/det|>
Remove the lid from beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 505, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
Place beaker A inside beaker B, as shown in Fig. 2.2, so that the water in beaker B rises between the sides of the two beakers.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 548, 650, 648]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 662, 532, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 692, 683, 710]]<|/det|>
Pour \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A and replace the lid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 707, 589, 725]]<|/det|>
Place the thermometer in the water in beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 738, 920, 772]]<|/det|>
In Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the water at time \(t = 0\) and immediately start the stop-watch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 785, 883, 803]]<|/det|>
Record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the water at \(t = 30 \text{s}, 60 \text{s}, 90 \text{s}, 120 \text{s}, 150 \text{s}\) and \(180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 800, 920, 819]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 584, 146, 602]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 584, 920, 616]]<|/det|> Write a conclusion stating in what way the temperature of the water surrounding beaker A affects the rate of cooling of the hot water in beaker A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 615, 670, 633]]<|/det|> Justify your answer by reference to values from your readings. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 739, 920, 757]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(R\) for beaker A cooling in **cold** water. Use your readings for beaker A from Table 2.1 and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 107, 567, 138]]<|/det|>
\[R = \frac{\theta_{\mathrm{A}0} - \theta_{\mathrm{A}180}}{T}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{\text{A}0}\) and \(\theta_{\text{A}180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker A at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit for the cooling rate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 240, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<form>R = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 144, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 747, 291]]<|/det|>
Another student repeats this experiment at the same room temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
State **one** other variable that she controls in order to obtain readings as close as possible to your readings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 411, 143, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
During the experiment, the increase in temperature of the water surrounding beaker A affects the results of the investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 458, 650, 477]]<|/det|>
Suggest **one** change to the experiment to reduce this effect.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 732, 90]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the focal length of a converging lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 579, 121]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 128, 910, 247]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 262, 532, 280]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 293, 144, 312]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 293, 180, 311]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 293, 813, 312]]<|/det|> Place the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the triangular illuminated object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 310, 460, 327]]<|/det|> Place the screen near the lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 325, 364, 343]]<|/det|> Switch on the lamp. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 339, 920, 373]]<|/det|> Move the screen until a clear focused image of the triangular illuminated object is seen on the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 384, 870, 403]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the distance \(\nu\) between the lens and the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 415, 759, 434]]<|/det|> Repeat the procedure for \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}, 40.0 \text{cm}, 50.0 \text{cm}\) and \(60.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 447, 359, 465]]<|/det|> Switch off the lamp. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 478, 541, 496]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 509, 682, 682]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 510, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the brightness of a lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the intensity (brightness) of the light produced by the lamp is affected by the current in the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 398, 166]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 366, 198]]<|/det|>
Â· a lamp and power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 667, 214]]<|/det|>
Â· a light meter which measures the intensity of light arriving at it

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 260, 229]]<|/det|>
Â· an ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 228, 310, 245]]<|/det|>
Â· a variable resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 473, 276]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 324, 306]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 918, 353]]<|/det|>
Â· complete the circuit diagram in Fig. 4.1 to show the variable resistor connected to control the current in the lamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 510, 369]]<|/det|>
Â· state the key variables to be kept constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 368, 490, 384]]<|/det|>
Â· explain briefly how to do the experiment

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 383, 918, 415]]<|/det|>
Â· draw a table with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 414, 606, 431]]<|/det|>
Â· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.
